page.title: 02 Barham's Geology
page.content: We live in the Elham valley.In our area we have many fields for crops(ie.wheat, barley,oilseed rape and sweet-corn) and grazing.There are areas of deciduous trees,some coppice, others parkland (with trees as old as 300 years).Using a chalky bank and grade 2 rich alluvial soil for comparative growth,one local farmer is experimenting with the growth of lupins and sunflowers.The hills are made of chalk ridges,that were once at the bottom of the sea,and contain the remains of hundreds of sea creatures. In time the earth changed shape.Now the sea bottom is well above sea level,forming our hills.There are also clay layers and flints.The flints were used for building locally.There are several examples in the village of Barham.Local water is pumped from underground where it has reached clay.
